questions.question_text: Which three components are part of the foundational information security principles of the CIA triad? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BEF
CIA
Confidentiality
Integrity
Availabitity

Selected Answer: BEF
Confidentiality, integrity and availability together are considered the three most important concepts within information security. Considering these three principles together within the framework of the "triad" can help guide the development of security policies for organizations.

https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Confidentiality-integrity-and-availability-CIA

Selected Answer: C
NFV (Network Functions Virtualization)

questions.question_text: What is an architectural framework created by ETSI that defines standards to decouple network functions from proprietary hardware-based appliances and have them run in software on standard x86 servers?

choices.C: uses policy-based forwarding of real-time traffic with less complexity
choices.A: uses FEC constructs for traffic forwarding, thereby improving efficiency

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A) No. That's not specific to SD-WAN
B) Yes. Separate data plane and control plane
C) No. Real-time traffic is focus on latency and QoS.
D) Yes. Exactly stated "SD-WAN unifies the WAN backbone" in below site:
https://www.kyndryl.com/in/en/learn/sd-wan
E) No. MPLS also can do that.

comments.content: the same link also sates that "SD-WAN handles future scenarios using centralized policy-based, real-time traffic steering ..." which contradicts your answer C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
The correct advantages of SD-WAN compared to MPLS-based connectivity are:
B. separates infrastructure and policy
E. manages failures through backup links

Selected Answer: CD
MPLS Vs SD-WAN
SD-WAN evolved from MPLS technology, which has powered private connectivity for more than two decades. In many ways, SD-WAN can be seen as a software abstraction of MPLS technology that's applicable to wider scenarios: It brings secure, private connectivity that's agnostic to all kinds of links and providers and is cloud-aware. While MPLS handled failure scenarios with backup links, SD-WAN handles them with real-time traffic steering based on centralised policy. Also, since SD-WAN unifies the entire WAN backbone, it delivers comprehensive analytics across the network globally. This wasn't possible before, because of disparate pieces of infrastructure and policy.

Selected Answer: AC
I disagree with the answers so far.
B - separates infrastructure and policy - So what? How is this an advantage?
D - unifies the WAN backbone - Again so what? How is this an advantage?
With A, you have FEC improving efficiency and C policy-based forwarding (link steering) and 
it reduces complexity as you would have to configure PBR for MPLS.
So A and C for me.
Answer is BD as per Cisco: https://www.cisco.com/c/en_uk/products/ios-nx-os-software/multiprotocol-label-switching-mpls/index.html

Selected Answer: CD
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/ios-nx-os-software/multiprotocol-label-switching-mpls/index.html

comments.content: Actually the same paragraph states also B... So I am confused

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Almost the same wording as here:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/enterprise-networks/sd-wan/what-is-sd-wan.html#~benefits

Selected Answer: BE
Most versions say BE

Selected Answer: CD
See this: 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en_uk/solutions/enterprise-networks/sd-wan/what-is-sd-wan.html#~benefits
"While MPLS handled failure scenarios with backup links, SD-WAN handles them with real-time traffic steering based on centralized policy. Also, since SD-WAN unifies the entire WAN backbone, it delivers comprehensive analytics across the network globally. This wasn't possible before, because of disparate pieces of infrastructure and policy."
- However, answers are saying something different than this sentence. go figure. it talks about "real time traffic steering" not "real time traffic". 
- Also says "disparate pieces of infrastructure and policy" before SD-WAN. Not that SD-WAN separates the infrastructure and policy.... 
So I'd say closest would be C&D

Selected Answer: CD
https://www.netify.com/learning/how-to-compare-sd-wan-vs-mpls

Selected Answer: BD
BD seems more accureate
BE is the ans - SDWAN separate data and control policy. It also take advantage of backup for failures

Selected Answer: BC
As per cisco

Selected Answer: AC
A and C to me.
I believe it's about traffic optimization:
FEC - remediates los over poor quality links;
PBR - "dynamic" routing for selected/critical applications.
BC seems correct?

questions.question_text: Which two features are advantages of SD-WAN compared to MPLS-based connectivity? (Choose two.)
Which two factors must be considered for high availability in campus LAN designs to mitigate concerns about unavailability of network resources? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A: Device resiliency: This refers to the ability of network devices to remain operational in the event of failure. This includes features such as redundant power supplies, hot-swappable components, and stateful failover.
D: Network resiliency: This refers to the ability of the network to continue to operate despite failures in individual devices or links. This can be achieved through features such as spanning tree protocol (STP), link aggregation, and redundant paths.

Selected Answer: AD
samk01 - why are you voting for "BD" whenever your answer states "AD"

Selected Answer: BD
The two factors that must be considered for high availability in campus LAN designs to mitigate concerns about unavailability of network resources are:

A: Device resiliency: This refers to the ability of network devices to remain operational in the event of failure. This includes features such as redundant power supplies, hot-swappable components, and stateful failover.
D: Network resiliency: This refers to the ability of the network to continue to operate despite failures in individual devices or links. This can be achieved through features such as spanning tree protocol (STP), link aggregation, and redundant paths.

choices.D: Design the network so that the routers connecting to other areas are Level 1/Level 2 routers and internal routers are Level 1
choices.B: Design the network so that the routers connecting to other areas are Level 2 routers and internal routers are Level 1
choices.C: Design the network so that all routers are Level 1 routers
choices.A: Design all routers as Level 2 routers. Set the links between the routers as Level 1 with the area

questions.question_text: Company XYZ is designing the IS-IS deployment strategy for their multiarea IS-IS domain. They want IS-IS neighbor relationships to be minimized on each network segment and want to optimize the size of the IS-IS LSDB on each router. Which can design can be used to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In this design, the routers connecting to other areas are configured as Level 1/Level 2 routers, also known as L1/L2 routers. L1/L2 routers have the capability to form adjacencies with both Level 1 routers within the same area and Level 2 routers in other areas. This allows for inter-area connectivity while minimizing the number of IS-IS neighbor relationships on each network segment.

Internal routers within each area are designated as Level 1 routers. They form adjacencies only with other Level 1 routers within the same area, reducing the LSDB size and neighbor relationships within each area.

This design approach enables inter-area routing through Level 1/Level 2 routers and intra-area routing within each area through Level 1 routers. It helps to minimize the number of neighbor relationships on each network segment while optimizing the LSDB size on each router.

Selected Answer: D
A Level-1 router must be connected to other areas through a Level-1-2 router. The Level-1-2 router maintains two LSDBs

Selected Answer: D
L1/L2 are mandatory for connecting different areas.

Selected Answer: B
By designating the boundary routers as Level 2, they will not form adjacency with each other on the same network segment, thus minimizing the number of neighbor relationships on each segment

comments.content: you statement may be true, but unless you deploy L1/L2 routers, your network will become fragmented as L1s cannot speak to other, non-adjacent areas. So D is correct

discussion.content:
B
(For D) Routers doing layer 1 & layer 2 role, needs to manage two LSDBs and the ask is to optimize the size of LSDB on each router.

comments.content: D should also add that backbone routers are L2-only. Unnecessary L1/L2 routers will cause additional L1 relationships between backbone routers. D is still the most correct one.
I think the answer is correct. only few routers are L2/L1. In B there will no adjacencies since L2 will never form adjacency with L1
